metadata.description: Zambian Lozi (SiLozi) as spoken in Western Province/Barotseland

examples: How are you - Mu cwani
How are you this morning - Mu cwani kakusasana
how are you.culturalContext: Standard greeting in Lozi culture. 'Mu cwani' is formal, 'mu kaufi' is informal.

examples: How much - Bukai
how much.usage: Common question when shopping or inquiring about price

examples: How are you feeling - U ikutwa cwani
how are you feeling.usage: Used when inquiring about someone's health or emotional state

examples: How have you been - Ne upila cwani
how have you been.usage: Used when meeting someone after some time

what is your name.translation: libizo la hao ki wena mang'i
what is your name.pronunciation: li-bi-zo la ha-o ki we-na mang-i
examples: What is your name - Libizo la hao ki wena mang'i
What are you doing - U eza ing'i
What are you cooking - U apeha ing'i
What are you eating - U ca ing'i
Are you okay, dear - U iketile wahesu nji
When are you coming - U taha lili
How was your night - Ulobezi cwani
How was your day - Utozi cwani
How are you doing - U cwang'i
How is your family - Lubasi lwa hao luzuha cwani
how is your family.culturalContext: Family well-being is important in Lozi culture

examples: What is wrong - King'i hape
What is wrong - Kufosahezi ng'i
what is wrong.usage: Used when sensing something is amiss

examples: What do you mean - Utalusa ng'i fo
What do you mean - Uling'i
How's the weather over there - Cwani siyemo sa lihalimu ko
Have you gone to church - Uile kwa keleke nji
have you gone to church.culturalContext: Reflects importance of religious practice in community

examples: What is this - King'i se
What's going on - Kuezahala ng'i
Are you listening - Wateleza nji
Are you listening - Wa utwa nji
Have you heard - Utwile nji
Can I go home - Nakona kuya kwa hae nji
Can I ask something - Ni kupa kubuza
How is everything - Lika lizamaya cwani

what's your phone number.translation: nombolo ya muhala wa hao ki ifi
what's your phone number.pronunciation: nom-bo-lo ya mu-ha-la wa ha-o ki i-fi
examples: What's your phone number - Nombolo ya muhala wa hao ki ifi
Can I visit you tomorrow - Ni kupotele kamuso
Stop that nonsense - Tuhela bwanganu bo
Wait a minute - Ikete pili
Wait a minute - Litela pili
Ooh! That is terribly bad - Mawe! Ki butata boo

what time do you knock off.translation: u caisa nako mani/u kotoka nako mani
what time do you knock off.pronunciation: u ca-i-sa na-ko ma-ni/u ko-to-ka na-ko ma-ni
examples: What time do you knock off - U caisa nako mani
What time do you knock off - U kotoka nako mani
I am tired today - Kacenu ni katezi
Good evening - Ki mazibwana
Good morning - Muzuhile
Good afternoon - Ki musihali
How are you - Mucwani

happy birthday.translation: takalezo yende ya lizazi la ku pepwa la hao
happy birthday.pronunciation: ta-ka-le-zo yen-de ya li-za-zi la ku pe-pwa la ha-o
examples: Happy birthday - Takalezo yende ya lizazi la ku pepwa la hao
Thank you - Ni itumezi
I am sorry - Ni kupa swalelo
You are welcome - Kozo
You are welcome - Ki hande
You are welcome - U tamboke
You are welcome - Kulukile
Me too - Ni na
God bless you - Mulimu a ku tonolofaze
God bless you - Mulimu a ku fuyole
god bless you.culturalContext: Reflects religious nature of Lozi communities

examples: May God protect you - Mulimu a kusileleze
may god protect you.culturalContext: Shows importance of divine protection in culture

examples: She is happy - U tabile
Please help me - Yela ni kupa tuso!
I don't know - A ni zibi

i will come tomorrow.translation: na taha kamuso/ni ka taha kamuso
i will come tomorrow.pronunciation: na ta-ha ka-mu-so/ni ka ta-ha ka-mu-so
examples: I will come tomorrow - Na taha kamuso
I will come tomorrow - Ni ka taha kamuso
Come here! - Taha kwanu!
Feel at home - Lukuluha
Feel at home - Ina ulukuluhile
Be blessed - Tonolofazwa
I am coming soon - Na taha cwanong'u fa
Excuse me - Kuti!
Excuse me - Na muniswalele
Leave me alone - Ni tuhele
Leave me alone - Ni siye ni nosi
It is okay - Kozo
It is okay - Ki hande
It is okay - Kulukile
I am going home - Ni ya kwa hae
I am going home - Ndu
I don't want - Na hana
I don't want - Ha ni bati
Love is a beautiful thing - Lilato kinto yende
Let me try - Ni like
Welcome home - Utamboke mwa lapa
Welcome home - Utamboke hae

i reached home safely.translation: ni fitile kwa lapa hande/ku sina butata
i reached home safely.pronunciation: ni fi-ti-le kwa la-pa han-de/ku si-na bu-ta-ta
examples: I reached home safely - Ni fitile kwa lapa hande
I reached home safely - Ni fitile kwa lapa ku sina butata
i reached home safely.culturalContext: Shows importance of confirming safe arrival
alternatives: ni fitile kwa lapa ku sina butata

examples: God is good - Mulimu ki yo munde
I don't understand - Ha ni utwisisi
We are happy to see you - Lutabile ku ku bona
I have it - Nina ni yona
How are you today - Ucwani kacenu
I am fine - Ni iketile
i am fine.culturalContext: Standard response to greetings in Lozi culture

examples: Have a good day - Mutole hande
Rest in peace - Pumula ka kozo
rest in peace.culturalContext: Used in condolences and memorial contexts

examples: I don't have money - Ha nina masheleng'i
I don't have money - Ha nina mali
I am done - Ni felize
I am going to the shop - Niya kwa sintolo
Happy New Year - Nyuwele!
Bad manners - Mikwa ye maswe

stop using your phone.translation: tuhela ku sebezisa foni ya hao
stop using your phone.pronunciation: tu-he-la ku se-be-zi-sa fo-ni ya ha-o
examples: Stop using your phone - Tuhela ku sebezisa foni ya hao
I need a favour, please - Ni kupa tuso yela!

i haven't seen you for ages.translation: seli kale ni ku boni!/seli nako ye telele lusabonani
i haven't seen you for ages.pronunciation: se-li ka-le ni ku bo-ni!/se-li na-ko ye te-le-le lu-sa-bo-na-ni
examples: I haven't seen you for ages - Seli kale ni ku boni!
I haven't seen you for ages - Seli nako ye telele lusabonani

great to see you again.translation: ki tabo ku ku bona hape
great to see you again.pronunciation: ki ta-bo ku ku bo-na ha-pe
examples: Great to see you again - Ki tabo ku ku bona hape
I really appreciate it - Na itumela luli
You made my day - Uni benyiselize lizazi laka kacenu
No problem - Hakuna butata
No problem - Ku lukile

thank god it's friday.translation: ni tabile kuli kacenu ki la butanu
thank god it's friday.pronunciation: ni ta-bi-le ku-li ka-ce-nu ki la bu-ta-nu
examples: Thank God it's Friday! - Ni tabile kuli kacenu ki la butanu!
There was a lot of traffic today - Mikwakwa ne ipatehile kacenu
We have a meeting this afternoon - Luna ni mukopano kacenu musihali
Let me take a nap! - Ni ipumulise kwateni!

this office is very dirty my dear.translation: ofisi ye wahesu itezi hahulu masila
this office is very dirty my dear.pronunciation: o-fi-si ye wa-he-su i-te-zi ha-hu-lu ma-si-la
examples: This office is very dirty my dear! - Ofisi ye wahesu itezi hahulu masila!

i wish i could have scones for lunch.translation: ni lakaza ku ca masikono sico sa musihali
i wish i could have scones for lunch.pronunciation: ni la-ka-za ku ca ma-si-ko-no si-co sa mu-si-ha-li
examples: I wish I could have scones for lunch! - Ni lakaza ku ca masikono sico sa musihali!
I am doing great - Ni iketile
i am doing great.culturalContext: Positive response to greetings in Lozi culture

examples: Hi - Yeela!
Nice to meet you - Kihande alukopani
nice to meet you.culturalContext: First meeting greeting in Lozi culture
nice to meet you.usage: Used when meeting someone for the first time

examples: See you soon - Luta bonana hape cwanong'u
see you soon.usage: Used when parting with expectation to meet soon

examples: See you later - Lukabonana kasamulaho
Welcome back - Mukutile
welcome back.culturalContext: Greeting for someone returning in Lozi culture
welcome back.usage: Used when greeting someone who has returned

examples: Enjoy your day - Muikole lizazi la kacenu
enjoy your day.usage: Used to wish someone a good day

examples: Pass my regards home - Balumele kwa lapa
pass my regards home.culturalContext: Common courtesy in Lozi culture to send greetings to family
pass my regards home.usage: Used to send greetings to someone's family

examples: My parents are greeting you - Litumeliso ze zwa kwa bashemisha
my parents are greeting you.culturalContext: Conveying greetings from family members is important in Lozi culture
my parents are greeting you.usage: Used to relay greetings from one's parents

examples: Get well by end of the day dear - Ufole lizazi alisikuluhile
get well by end of the day dear.culturalContext: Well-wishing phrase for someone who is unwell in Lozi culture
get well by end of the day dear.usage: Used to wish quick recovery for someone who is sick

examples: I love you - Na kulata
i love you.culturalContext: Expression of romantic affection in Lozi culture

examples: I miss you - Ni kutondile
i miss you.culturalContext: Expression of longing in Lozi culture

examples: Love you so much - Ni kulata hahulu
love you so much.culturalContext: Strong expression of romantic affection in Lozi culture

examples: I want to see you - Ni bata ku kubona
i want to see you.culturalContext: Expression of desire to meet in Lozi culture
i want to see you.usage: Used to express desire to meet someone

i love you with all my heart.translation: ni kulata ka pilu ye sweu
i love you with all my heart.pronunciation: ni ku-la-ta ka pi-lu ye swe-u
examples: I love you with all my heart - Ni kulata ka pilu ye sweu
i love you with all my heart.culturalContext: Deep expression of love in Lozi culture
i love you with all my heart.usage: Used to express sincere and deep love

examples: I love you too - Na kulat ni na
i love you too.culturalContext: Reciprocal expression of love in Lozi culture
i love you too.usage: Used to reciprocate an expression of love

examples: I like you - Na kulata
i like you.culturalContext: Expression of affection in Lozi culture
i like you.usage: Used to express affection or attraction

examples: You are beautiful - Uyo munde
My love - Wahesu
my love.culturalContext: Term of endearment in Lozi culture
my love.usage: Used as a term of endearment for a romantic partner

examples: You look beautiful - Ubonahala hande
My beautiful wife - Musalaka yo munde
my beautiful wife.culturalContext: Term of endearment for a spouse in Lozi culture
my beautiful wife.usage: Used by husbands to refer to their wives affectionately

i miss you so much, darling.translation: na ku tonda luli wa lilato
i miss you so much, darling.pronunciation: na ku ton-da lu-li wa li-la-to
examples: I miss you so much, darling - Na ku tonda luli wa lilato
i miss you so much, darling.culturalContext: Expression of deep longing in Lozi culture
i miss you so much, darling.usage: Used to express strong feelings of missing a loved one

examples: I need you - Na kutokwa
i need you.culturalContext: Expression of emotional dependency in Lozi culture
i need you.usage: Used to express emotional need for someone

examples: You will miss me - U ka ni tokwa
you will miss me.culturalContext: Expression in Lozi culture about future longing
you will miss me.usage: Used to express that someone will feel one's absence

examples: Goodbye, my love - Siyala fo wa lilato
goodbye, my love.culturalContext: Farewell expression to a loved one in Lozi culture
goodbye, my love.usage: Used when parting with a romantic partner

examples: See you tomorrow - Ni kakubona kamuso
see you tomorrow.usage: Used when parting with plans to meet the next day

examples: I will marry you - Ni ka kunyala
i will marry you.culturalContext: Marriage proposal or commitment in Lozi culture
i will marry you.usage: Used to propose marriage or express commitment

examples: I want some space - Ni tokwa sibakanyana
i want some space.culturalContext: Expression of need for personal space in Lozi culture
i want some space.usage: Used to request personal space in a relationship

examples: I need your love - Ni tokwa lilato lahao
i need your love.culturalContext: Expression of emotional need in Lozi culture
i need your love.usage: Used to express need for someone's affection

examples: You are mine - Wena u waka!
you are mine.culturalContext: Expression of possessiveness in romantic relationships in Lozi culture

examples: My wife is pretty - Mufumahali wa buheha
my wife is pretty.culturalContext: Compliment about one's spouse in Lozi culture
my wife is pretty.usage: Used by husbands to compliment their wives

what a pretty girl she is.translation: batili ki licolocolo mbonyi ya siloko
what a pretty girl she is.pronunciation: ba-ti-li ki li-co-lo-co-lo mbo-nyi ya si-lo-ko
examples: What a pretty girl she is! - Batili ki licolocolo mbonyi ya siloko!
what a pretty girl she is.culturalContext: Expression of admiration in Lozi culture
what a pretty girl she is.usage: Used to express admiration for a woman's beauty

examples: How much was the dowry? - Lionda neili bukai?
how much was the dowry.culturalContext: Question about traditional marriage practices in Lozi culture
how much was the dowry.usage: Used to inquire about bride price in a traditional marriage

examples: I really love her - Ni mulata maswe
i really love her.culturalContext: Expression of strong affection in Lozi culture
i really love her.usage: Used to express deep affection for a woman

examples: She has beautiful eyes - Meto a hae sina muzilili
Hello, how are you? - Lumela, mu cwani?
Hello everyone - Lumela kaufela
hello.culturalContext: Universal greeting used in most situations in Lozi communities.

examples: Where are you? - Ukai?
where are you.culturalContext: Basic question about location in Lozi culture
where are you.usage: Common question to determine someone's location

examples: Where did you go? - Ne u ile kai?
where did you go.culturalContext: Question about past movement in Lozi culture
where did you go.usage: Used to ask about someone's previous destination

examples: Where do you live? - Ne wina kai?
where do you live.culturalContext: Question about residence in Lozi culture
where do you live.usage: Used to ask where someone resides

examples: Where are you going? - Uya kai?
where are you going.culturalContext: Question about destination in Lozi culture
where are you going.usage: Common question to ask about someone's destination

examples: Where were you? - Ne u inzi kai?
where were you.culturalContext: Question about past location in Lozi culture
where were you.usage: Used to ask about someone's previous location

examples: How far are you? - U zamaela kai?
how far are you.culturalContext: Question about distance in Lozi culture
how far are you.usage: Used to ask about someone's distance from a reference point

our village is on the northern side of t.translation: munzi wa luna ukwa mutulo wa sikolo
our village is on the northern side of t.pronunciation: mun-zi wa lu-na u-kwa mu-tu-lo wa si-ko-lo
examples: Our village is on the northern side of the school - Munzi wa luna ukwa mutulo wa sikolo
our village is on the northern side of t.culturalContext: Description of location using cardinal directions in Lozi culture
our village is on the northern side of t.usage: Used to describe the location of a village relative to a landmark

how far do you stay from the hospital.translation: sipatela si kwahule cwani ku zwa fo muina
how far do you stay from the hospital.pronunciation: si-pa-te-la si kwa-hu-le cwa-ni ku zwa fo mu-i-na
examples: How far do you stay from the hospital? - Sipatela si kwahule cwani ku zwa fo muina?
how far do you stay from the hospital.culturalContext: Question about distance from a specific landmark in Lozi culture
how far do you stay from the hospital.usage: Used to ask about the distance between someone's residence and a location

we stay in yeta compound because it's ne.translation: luina mwa Yeta kakuli ifakaufi ni tolopo
we stay in yeta compound because it's ne.pronunciation: lu-i-na mwa Ye-ta ka-ku-li i-fa-ka-u-fi ni to-lo-po
examples: We stay in Yeta compound because it's near town - Luina mwa Yeta kakuli ifakaufi ni tolopo
we stay in yeta compound because it's ne.culturalContext: Explanation of residence choice based on location in Lozi culture
we stay in yeta compound because it's ne.usage: Used to explain residential choice based on proximity to town

ripe fruits fall down not upwards.translation: litolwana ze buzwize liwela fa fasi ising'i mwa halimu
ripe fruits fall down not upwards.pronunciation: li-tol-wa-na ze bu-zwi-ze li-we-la fa fa-si i-sing'i mwa ha-li-mu
examples: Ripe fruits fall down not upwards - Litolwana ze buzwize liwela fa fasi ising'i mwa halimu
ripe fruits fall down not upwards.culturalContext: Traditional proverb in Lozi culture that teaches natural laws and order
ripe fruits fall down not upwards.usage: Used metaphorically to teach about natural order or to indicate that things have predictable outcomes

examples: Thank you for your help - Ni itumezi ka tuso ya hao
Thank you very much - Ni itumezi hahulu
thank you.culturalContext: Expressing gratitude is important in Lozi culture and shows respect.
thank you.usage: Used to express gratitude for help, gifts, or services

examples: Goodbye, see you tomorrow - Mu siale hande, ni ka mi bona kamuso
Goodbye everyone - Mu siale hande kaufela
goodbye.culturalContext: Said by the person who is leaving. Literally means 'stay well'.

examples: Yes, I understand - Ee, na utwisisa
Yes, that's correct - Ee, ki niti
yes.culturalContext: Simple affirmative response used in various social contexts.
yes.usage: Used to express agreement or affirmation

examples: No, I don't want that - Batili, ha ni lati cwalo
No, thank you - Batili, ni itumezi
no.culturalContext: Negative response that is considered polite in Lozi conversation.
no.usage: Used to express disagreement or denial

examples: Please help me - Shangwe ni tuse
Please sit down - Shangwe ina fafasi
please.culturalContext: Used to make requests more polite, showing respect for the other person.
please.usage: Polite request marker preceding commands or requests

examples: I'm sorry for being late - Ni swabile ka ku liyeha
I'm very sorry - Ni swabile hahulu
sorry.culturalContext: Used for apologies and expressing sympathy in Lozi culture.

examples: I need water - Ni tokwa mezi
The water is clean - Mezi a kenile
water.culturalContext: Essential resource in daily Lozi life
water.usage: Refers to the liquid used for drinking and other purposes

examples: I want bread - Ni bata mbolo
Fresh bread - Mbolo ye nca
bread.culturalContext: Important staple food in Lozi communities

examples: The food is delicious - Lico li munanani
Let's prepare food - Ha lu apehe lico
food.culturalContext: Communal eating is important in Lozi culture, with meals often shared from common dishes.

examples: I want more - Ni bata hape
Please talk more - Shangwe bulela hape
more.culturalContext: Used in various contexts to request additional items or actions in Lozi conversation.

examples: I want less sugar - Ni bata swikili nyinyani
There is less water today - Kuna mezi nyinyani kacenu
less.culturalContext: Used to indicate reduced quantity in Lozi households and marketplaces.
less.usage: Indicates smaller quantity when discussing amounts

examples: That's enough food - Lico zeo li kulikana
I have enough money - Ni na ni mashelei a kulikana
enough.culturalContext: Indicates satisfaction with current quantity in social and commercial settings.
enough.usage: Expresses sufficient quantity when discussing amounts

examples: This is my house - Ye ki ndu yaka
The house is big - Ndu ki yetuna
house.culturalContext: Traditional Lozi houses were round with thatched roofs, though modern houses vary in style.
house.usage: Refers to physical building where people live

examples: I'm going home - Ni ya kwa lapa
My home is far from here - Lapa laka li kwahule ni fa
home.culturalContext: Distinct from 'house' as it connotes family dwelling and emotional connection.
home.usage: Refers to one's place of residence with family

examples: The children are at school - Bana ba kwa sikolo
The school is closed today - Sikolo si kwalilwe kacenu
school.culturalContext: Education is highly valued in contemporary Lozi society.
school.usage: Refers to place of education or learning institution

examples: I need one book - Ni tokwa buka iliwi
There is one person waiting - Kuna mutu alimuwi ya libelela
one.culturalContext: Numbers in Lozi often have prefixes that change based on the class of noun they modify.
one.usage: Used for counting and indicating single items

examples: I have two children - Ni na ni bana babeli
Give me two fish - Ni fe litapi zepeli
two.culturalContext: Number prefixes vary based on noun class agreement in Lozi grammar.
two.usage: Used for counting and indicating pairs of items

examples: I will go today - Ni ka ya kacenu
Today is a good day - Kacenu ki lizazi lelinde
today.culturalContext: Time expressions in Lozi are important for planning activities and socializing.
today.usage: Refers to the current day when speaking

examples: I will see you tomorrow - Ni ka ku bona kamuso
Tomorrow we will work - Kamuso lu ka beleka
tomorrow.culturalContext: Planning for the future is expressed through time references in Lozi.
tomorrow.usage: Refers to the day after today

examples: I want to eat - Ni bata ku ca
They are eating now - Ba ca cwale
to eat.culturalContext: Meals are important social occasions in Lozi culture, often eaten communally.
to eat.usage: Describes the action of consuming food

examples: I want to drink water - Ni bata ku nwa mezi
He is drinking milk - U nwa mabisi
to drink.culturalContext: Traditional drinks in Lozi culture include maheu (fermented maize drink) and milk.
to drink.usage: Describes the action of consuming liquids

examples: My brother is tall - Muzwale waka ki mutelele
I have three brothers - Ni na ni bazwale babalalu
brother.culturalContext: Family relationships are highly valued in Lozi culture, with specific terms for different relatives.
brother.usage: Refers to male sibling or male cousin in extended usage

examples: My sister is at school - Kezela waka u kwa sikolo
She is like a sister to me - Ki inge kezela ku na
sister.culturalContext: In Lozi culture, the term can extend to female cousins and close female friends.
sister.usage: Refers to female sibling or female cousin in extended usage

examples: My mother is cooking - Me waka wa apeha
Where is your mother? - Me hao u kai?
mother.culturalContext: Mothers hold an important position in Lozi family structures and are highly respected.
mother.usage: Refers to female parent, can also be used respectfully for older women

examples: My father works in the field - Ndate waka u beleka mwa simu
Ask your father - Buza ndate hao
father.culturalContext: Fathers are traditionally heads of households in Lozi culture, though family structures are evolving.
father.usage: Refers to male parent, can also be used respectfully for older men

examples: The child is sleeping - Mwana u lobezi
Whose child is this? - Ki mwana wa mai yo?
child.culturalContext: Children are valued in Lozi communities and raising them is considered a communal responsibility.
child.usage: Refers to young person in relation to parents or generally

examples: The children are playing - Bana ba bapala
I teach children - Ni luta bana
children.culturalContext: Plural form of 'mwana'. Children are highly valued in Lozi society.
children.usage: Refers to multiple young people collectively

examples: This is my friend - Yo ki mulikanaa ka
I'm going with my friend - Ni ya ni mulikanaa ka
friend.culturalContext: Friendships are important social bonds in Lozi communities, often formed through shared activities.
friend.usage: Refers to person with whom one has a close, non-family relationship

examples: I don't have money - Ha ni na mashelei
How much money do you need? - U tokwa mashelei a makuma kai?
money.culturalContext: Currency used in modern Lozi society, replacing traditional barter systems.
money.usage: Refers to currency used for economic transactions

examples: I'm going to the market - Ni ya kwa musika
The market is closed today - Musika u kwalilwe kacenu
market.culturalContext: Markets are important social and commercial hubs in Lozi communities.
market.usage: Refers to place where goods are bought and sold

examples: The sun is hot today - Lizazi li cisa kacenu
We work until the sun sets - Lu beleka kufitela lizazi li likela
sun.culturalContext: Important in agricultural timing and daily routines in Lozi communities.
sun.usage: Refers to the star at the center of our solar system

examples: The moon is bright tonight - Kweli i benya busihu cwana
There's a full moon - Kuna kweli ye tezi
moon.culturalContext: The moon phases are traditionally used to track time and plan agricultural activities.

examples: It's raining - Ku na pula
We need rain for our crops - Lu tokwa pula ya limela zaluna
rain.culturalContext: Rain is celebrated in Lozi culture as essential for agriculture and life, especially in Western Province.
rain.usage: Refers to water falling from clouds

examples: This is good food - Lico le ki lelinde
He is a good person - Ki mutu yomunde
good.culturalContext: Used to express approval in various contexts in Lozi conversation.
good.usage: Describes positive quality of things, people, or situations

examples: This is bad weather - Nako ye ki yemaswe
That's a bad idea - Muhupulo wo ki omaswe
bad.culturalContext: Used to express disapproval in various contexts in Lozi conversation.
bad.usage: Describes negative quality of things, people, or situations

examples: I live in this village - Ni pila mwa munzi wo
Our village is near the river - Munzi waluna u fakaufi ni nuka
village.culturalContext: Traditional settlements in Lozi areas, often organized around extended family groups or community ties.

examples: The Zambezi is a big river - Zambezi ki nuka yetuna
We fish in the river - Lu yamba mwa nuka
river.culturalContext: Rivers, especially the Zambezi, are central to Lozi life, culture, and migration patterns.
river.usage: Refers to natural flowing water body

examples: I caught a fish - Ni swasile tapi
This fish tastes good - Tapi ye i na ni munanana
fish.culturalContext: Fishing is an important economic and subsistence activity in the Zambezi floodplains.
fish.usage: Refers to aquatic animal caught for food

examples: The cow gives milk - Komu i fa mabisi
He has many cows - Una ni likomu zeata
cow.culturalContext: Cattle are traditionally symbols of wealth and status in Lozi culture.
cow.usage: Refers to domesticated bovine animal kept for milk and meat

examples: I like to walk - Ni lata ku zamaya
They are walking to school - Ba zamaya ku ya kwa sikolo
to walk.culturalContext: Walking is the primary mode of transportation in many rural Lozi communities.
to walk.usage: Describes action of moving on foot

examples: I work at the hospital - Ni beleka kwa sipatela
He works hard - U beleka ka tata
to work.culturalContext: Work ethic is valued in Lozi communities, with different types of work traditionally divided by gender.
to work.usage: Describes action of performing labor or duties

examples: I want to sleep - Ni bata ku lobala
The baby is sleeping - Mbututu u lobezi
to sleep.culturalContext: Sleeping arrangements in traditional Lozi households often involve shared sleeping areas.
to sleep.usage: Describes state of rest with eyes closed and reduced consciousness

examples: The chicken is laying eggs - Kuhu i beya maqanda
We ate chicken yesterday - Ne lu cile kuhu maabani
chicken.culturalContext: Chickens are commonly kept in Lozi homesteads for eggs and meat, and are often managed by women.
chicken.usage: Refers to domesticated bird kept for eggs and meat

examples: The goat is eating grass - Puli i ca bwangu
My father has ten goats - Ndate waka una ni lipuli ze lishumi
goat.culturalContext: Goats are important livestock in Lozi communities, used for meat and sometimes milk.
goat.usage: Refers to small domesticated ruminant animal

examples: Rest in peace - Pumula ka kozo
rest in peace.culturalContext: Used in condolences and memorial contexts

examples: I don't have money - Ha nina masheleng'i
I don't have money - Ha nina mali
I am done - Ni felize
I am going to the shop - Niya kwa sintolo
Happy New Year - Nyuwele!
Bad manners - Mikwa ye maswe

stop using your phone.translation: tuhela ku sebezisa foni ya hao
stop using your phone.pronunciation: tu-he-la ku se-be-zi-sa fo-ni ya ha-o
examples: Stop using your phone - Tuhela ku sebezisa foni ya hao
I need a favour, please - Ni kupa tuso yela!

i haven't seen you for ages.translation: seli kale ni ku boni!/seli nako ye telele lusabonani
i haven't seen you for ages.pronunciation: se-li ka-le ni ku bo-ni!/se-li na-ko ye te-le-le lu-sa-bo-na-ni
examples: I haven't seen you for ages - Seli kale ni ku boni!
I haven't seen you for ages - Seli nako ye telele lusabonani

great to see you again.translation: ki tabo ku ku bona hape
great to see you again.pronunciation: ki ta-bo ku ku bo-na ha-pe
examples: Great to see you again - Ki tabo ku ku bona hape
I really appreciate it - Na itumela luli
You made my day - Uni benyiselize lizazi laka kacenu
No problem - Hakuna butata
No problem - Ku lukile

thank god it's friday.translation: ni tabile kuli kacenu ki la butanu
thank god it's friday.pronunciation: ni ta-bi-le ku-li ka-ce-nu ki la bu-ta-nu
examples: Thank God it's Friday! - Ni tabile kuli kacenu ki la butanu!
There was a lot of traffic today - Mikwakwa ne ipatehile kacenu
We have a meeting this afternoon - Luna ni mukopano kacenu musihali
Let me take a nap! - Ni ipumulise kwateni!

this office is very dirty my dear.translation: ofisi ye wahesu itezi hahulu masila
this office is very dirty my dear.pronunciation: o-fi-si ye wa-he-su i-te-zi ha-hu-lu ma-si-la
examples: This office is very dirty my dear! - Ofisi ye wahesu itezi hahulu masila!

i wish i could have scones for lunch.translation: ni lakaza ku ca masikono sico sa musihali
i wish i could have scones for lunch.pronunciation: ni la-ka-za ku ca ma-si-ko-no si-co sa mu-si-ha-li
examples: I wish I could have scones for lunch! - Ni lakaza ku ca masikono sico sa musihali!
The dog is barking - Nja i lila
I have two dogs - Ni na ni linja zepeli
dog.culturalContext: Dogs are kept as guard animals and for hunting in traditional Lozi villages.
dog.usage: Refers to domesticated canine kept as pet or guard animal

examples: The sheep are grazing - Lingu li fula
He sells sheep at the market - U lekisa lingu kwa musika
sheep.culturalContext: Less common than goats in traditional Lozi areas but kept for wool and meat.
sheep.usage: Refers to domesticated wooly ruminant animal

examples: The pig is in the mud - Kulube i mwa sileze
They are raising pigs - Ba hula likulube
pig.culturalContext: Pigs are raised for meat in some Lozi communities, though less common than cattle.
pig.usage: Refers to domesticated swine raised for meat

examples: We saw an elephant near the river - Ne lu boni tou fakaufi ni nuka
The elephant is a symbol of wisdom - Tou ki sisupo sa butali
elephant.culturalContext: Elephants are respected in Lozi cultural heritage and feature in traditional stories.
elephant.usage: Refers to large wild mammal with trunk and tusks

examples: The lion is hunting - Tau i zuma
The lion is the king of the animals - Tau ki mulena wa lifolofolo
lion.culturalContext: Lions symbolize power and leadership in Lozi cultural references.
lion.usage: Refers to large wild cat, apex predator

examples: We work in the field - Lu beleka mwa simu
The field is ready for planting - Simu se i lukisizwe kwa ku cala
field.culturalContext: Agricultural fields are important spaces in Lozi communities, where staple crops are grown.
field.usage: Refers to area of land used for growing crops

examples: The maize is growing well - Mbonyi i hula hande
We harvest maize in May - Lu kutula mbonyi mwa Kandao
maize.culturalContext: Maize is a staple crop in Lozi agriculture, used to make nshima (thick porridge).
maize.usage: Refers to cereal crop with large grain-laden cobs

examples: We planted cassava - Ne lu calile mundongo
Cassava grows well in sandy soil - Mundongo u hula hande mwa mubu wa lishabati
cassava.culturalContext: Important food crop in Lozi cuisine, particularly in the floodplains.
cassava.usage: Refers to root crop with starchy tubers

examples: We cook beans with vegetables - Lu apeha manawa ni miloho
The beans are ready to harvest - Manawa a lukela ku kutuliwa
beans.culturalContext: Common crop grown for protein in Lozi communities, often intercropped with maize.
beans.usage: Refers to legume crop grown for edible seeds

examples: I need seeds for planting - Ni tokwa lipeu za ku cala
These are good seeds - Lipeu ze ki zelinde
seed.culturalContext: Seed saving and exchange is a traditional practice in Lozi agriculture.
seed.usage: Refers to plant embryo used for propagation

examples: The harvest was good this year - Buoli neli bunde mwaha wo
We celebrate after the harvest - Lu keteka kasamulaho a buoli
harvest.culturalContext: Harvest time is celebrated in Lozi communities with traditional ceremonies.
harvest.usage: Refers to gathering of mature crops from the field

examples: We plant seeds in November - Lu cala lipeu mwa Yowa
I'm planting maize today - Ni cala mbonyi kacenu
to plant.culturalContext: Planting is timed according to seasonal patterns, often at the start of the rainy season.
to plant.usage: Describes action of putting seeds or seedlings in soil

examples: We harvest when the crops are ready - Lu kutula limela ha li buzwize
They are harvesting cassava - Ba kutula mundongo
to harvest.culturalContext: Harvesting is often a communal activity in traditional Lozi communities.
to harvest.usage: Describes action of gathering mature crops from field

examples: I need a new hoe - Ni tokwa sebilo sesinca
We cultivate with hoes - Lu lima ka libilo
hoe.culturalContext: Traditional farming tool used in Lozi agriculture for centuries.
hoe.usage: Refers to hand tool used for cultivating soil

examples: We use oxen to pull the plow - Lu itusisa likomu ku hohela makoloya
The plow breaks the soil - Makoloya a puma mubu
plow.culturalContext: Introduced during colonial period but now integrated into Lozi farming practices.
plow.usage: Refers to agricultural implement used to turn soil

examples: My mother is cooking dinner - Me waka u apeha mulalelo
I'm learning to cook - Ni ituta ku apeha
to cook.culturalContext: Cooking is traditionally done by women in Lozi households, often over wood fires.
to cook.usage: Describes action of preparing food with heat

examples: I wash clothes every Saturday - Ni tapa liapalo kamita la Pelekelo
She is washing dishes - U tapa mikeke
to wash.culturalContext: Washing clothes and dishes is often done at water sources in rural Lozi communities.
to wash.usage: Describes action of cleaning with water

examples: I clean my house every morning - Ni kenisa ndu yaka kakusasana kamita
We need to clean the yard - Lu tokwa ku kenisa lapa
to clean.culturalContext: Cleanliness of homes and surroundings is valued in Lozi culture.
to clean.usage: Describes action of removing dirt or mess

examples: My father farms for a living - Ndate waka u lima kwa pila
They farm near the river - Ba lima fakaufi ni nuka
to farm.culturalContext: Farming is a primary occupation in rural Lozi communities, with methods adapted to local conditions.
to farm.usage: Describes action of cultivating land for crops

examples: We fish in the Zambezi - Lu yamba mwa Zambezi
He is fishing with a net - U yamba ka kanyandi
to fish.culturalContext: Fishing is important in Lozi communities near rivers and floodplains.

examples: I milk the cows in the morning - Ni hama likomu kakusasana
He is teaching his son to milk - U luta mwanaa hae ku hama
to milk.culturalContext: Milking cattle is traditionally done by men in Lozi pastoral communities.
to milk.usage: Describes action of extracting milk from animals

examples: Men used to hunt in the forest - Baana ne ba zuma mwa mushitu
They hunt with spears - Ba zuma ka malumo
to hunt.culturalContext: Traditional hunting practices have cultural significance though less common today.
to hunt.usage: Describes action of pursuing animals for food

examples: Good morning - Muzuhile kakusasana
I work in the morning - Ni beleka kakusasana
morning.culturalContext: Mornings are active times in Lozi communities, when many chores and activities begin.
morning.usage: Refers to early part of the day

examples: Good evening - Muzuhile manzibwana
We eat dinner in the evening - Lu ca mulalelo manzibwana
evening.culturalContext: Evening time often brings families together after the day's work is done.
evening.usage: Refers to later part of the day before night

examples: I sleep at night - Ni lobala busihu
The stars shine at night - Linaleli li benya busihu
night.culturalContext: Traditionally a time for rest and storytelling in Lozi households.
night.usage: Refers to time of darkness when most people sleep

examples: The tree provides shade - Kota i fa muluti
There are many trees by the river - Kuna ni likota zeata kwa nuka
tree.culturalContext: Trees have practical and spiritual significance in Lozi culture, with some species considered sacred.
tree.usage: Refers to woody perennial plant with trunk and branches

examples: The cows eat grass - Likomu li ca bwangu
The grass is green after the rain - Bwangu bu butala kasamulaho a pula
grass.culturalContext: Important for livestock grazing in Lozi pastoral communities.
grass.usage: Refers to low-growing green plants in lawns or fields

examples: The flower smells nice - Palisa i nuka hande
She likes flowers - U lata lipalisa
flower.culturalContext: Some flowers have medicinal uses in traditional Lozi healing practices.
flower.usage: Refers to bloom or blossom of a plant

examples: The mountain is high - Lilundu li pahami
They live near the mountains - Ba pila fakaufi ni malundu
mountain.culturalContext: Geographical features figure in Lozi origin stories and historical movements.
mountain.usage: Refers to large natural elevation of earth's surface

examples: Happy New Year - Mwaha omunde onca
I lived there for five years - Ni pilile tei ka myaha ye ketalizoho
year.culturalContext: The Lozi calendar traditionally tracked years according to agricultural cycles and floods.
year.usage: Refers to period of twelve months

examples: Which month is it? - Ki kweli mai ye?
I'll see you next month - Ni ka ku bona kweli ye tatama
month.culturalContext: Same word as 'moon', reflecting traditional lunar calendar system.
month.usage: Refers to one of twelve divisions of the year

examples: See you next week - Ni ka ku bona sunda ye tatama
I work five days a week - Ni beleka mazazi a ketalizoho ka sunda
week.culturalContext: The seven-day week was introduced with European contact but is now standard.
week.usage: Refers to period of seven days

examples: Today is a good day - Lizazi la kacenu ki lelinde
Two days ago - Mazazi amabeli a fitile
day.culturalContext: Same word as 'sun', reflecting the connection between daylight and the sun.
day.usage: Refers to period from sunrise to sunset or 24-hour period

examples: My head hurts - Toho yaka ya opisa
She has a big head - Una ni toho yetuna
head.culturalContext: The head is considered an important and respected part of the body in Lozi culture.
head.usage: Refers to upper part of human body containing brain

examples: His eyes are brown - Meeto a hae ki amabala
I have something in my eye - Ni na ni sesiwi mwa liito laka
eye.culturalContext: Eye contact has specific cultural meanings in Lozi interactions.

examples: Wash your hands - Tapa mazoho a hao
Give me your hand - Ni fe lizoho la hao
hand.culturalContext: Hand washing before meals is an important practice in Lozi households.
hand.usage: Refers to end part of arm including fingers

examples: My foot hurts - Lihutu laka la opisa
He has big feet - Una ni mahutu amatuna
foot.culturalContext: Feet are considered lower status in Lozi body hierarchy and should be kept clean.
foot.usage: Refers to end part of leg including toes

examples: My heart is beating fast - Pilu yaka i nata kapili
He has a kind heart - Una ni pilu yende
heart.culturalContext: The heart is considered the center of emotions in Lozi cultural expressions.
heart.usage: Refers to organ that pumps blood and metaphorically to emotions

examples: I am happy - Ni tabile
It's a happy occasion - Ki nako ya tabo
happy.culturalContext: Celebrations and expressions of happiness are important in Lozi community events.
happy.usage: Describes feeling of joy or contentment

examples: She is sad - U swabile
It's a sad story - Ki likande la maswabi
sad.culturalContext: Expressions of sadness are regulated by social norms in Lozi culture.
sad.usage: Describes feeling of unhappiness or sorrow

examples: He is angry with me - U ni halezi
Don't be angry - U si ke wa halifa
angry.culturalContext: Direct expressions of anger are often discouraged in traditional Lozi etiquette.

examples: The sun is hot - Lizazi li cisa hahulu
This food is hot - Lico le li cisa
hot.culturalContext: The dry season in Western Province can be extremely hot, affecting daily activities.
hot.usage: Describes high temperature or spicy taste

examples: The water is cold - Mezi a pola
It's cold this morning - Ku pola kakusasana cwana
cold.culturalContext: Cold season in Barotseland occurs during the dry months of May to August.

examples: That's a big house - Yani ki ndu yetuna
He has a big family - Una ni lubasi lolutuna
big.culturalContext: Size descriptions are important in Lozi marketplace transactions and storytelling.

examples: This is a small fish - Ye ki tapi yenyinyani
The child is small - Mwana u nyinyani
small.culturalContext: Diminutive descriptions have specific social uses in Lozi conversation.
small.usage: Describes small size or minimal importance

examples: The children are laughing - Bana ba seha
That makes me laugh - Seo si ni seisa
to laugh.culturalContext: Laughter is an important part of social bonding in Lozi community gatherings.
to laugh.usage: Describes action of showing amusement with sound

examples: The baby is crying - Mbututu wa lila
Don't cry - U si ke wa lila
to cry.culturalContext: Expression of grief through crying is culturally regulated with specific expectations.
to cry.usage: Describes action of shedding tears, often from emotion

examples: How are you young man? - Mu cwani mushimani?
Good morning, how are you young man? - Lumela, mu cwani mushimani?
how are you young man.culturalContext: Respectful greeting to a young male, acknowledging their youth status
how are you young man.usage: Common greeting phrase used when addressing a young man or boy

examples: How are you young girl? - Mu cwani mwanana?
Good morning, how are you young girl? - Lumela, mu cwani mwanana?
how are you young girl.culturalContext: Respectful greeting to a young female, acknowledging their youth status
how are you young girl.usage: Common greeting phrase used when addressing a young girl or female child

where can I find mango trees.translation: ni kona ku fumana likota za mango kai
where can I find mango trees.pronunciation: ni ko-na ku fu-ma-na li-ko-ta za ma-ngo ka-i
examples: Where can I find mango trees? - Ni kona ku fumana likota za mango kai?
I want to know where I can find mango trees - Ni bata ku ziba ni kona ku fumana likota za mango kai
where can I find mango trees.culturalContext: Mangoes are popular fruits in Western Province of Zambia, though not native to the region. They were introduced during colonial times and are now grown along the Zambezi River.
where can I find mango trees.usage: Useful phrase when looking for specific fruit trees or resources in a new area

examples: Get pregnant and get paid - Imita ufole
She wants to get pregnant and get paid - U bata ku imita ufole
get pregnant and get paid.culturalContext: Expression used in contexts related to pregnancy and financial matters or support
get pregnant and get paid.usage: Social commentary phrase that can be used in discussions about relationships and responsibility
